quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Set Operation[/h1]

Occasionally, you might need to combine data from multiple tables into one comprehensive dataset. This may be for tables with similar data within the same database or maybe there is a need to combine similar data across databases or even across servers. 

To accomplish this, use the [b]UNION [/b]and [b]UNION ALL[/b] operators. 

[b]UNION [/b]combines multiple datasets into a single dataset, and removes any existing duplicates.
[b]UNION ALL[/b] combines multiple datasets into one dataset, but does not remove duplicate rows. 
[note]UNION ALL is faster than UNION, as it does not perform the duplicate removal operation over the data set.[/note]

quizzes.question: To perform a union operation:
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]UNION[/h1]

The [b]UNION [/b]operator is used to combine the result-sets of two or more SELECT statements.

All SELECT statements within the UNION must have the [b]same number of columns[/b]. The columns must also have the same[b] data types[/b]. Also, the columns in each SELECT statement must be in the same order.
The syntax of UNION is as follows: [code format="sql"]SELECT column_name(s) FROM table1
[b]UNION[/b]
SELECT column_name(s) FROM table2;[/code]
Here is the [b]First [/b]of two tables: [img id="2840" width="100%"]
And here is the [b]Second[/b]: [img id="2841" width="100%"]
[code format="sql"]SELECT ID, FirstName, LastName, City FROM First
[b]UNION[/b]
SELECT ID, FirstName, LastName, City FROM Second;[/code]
The resulting table will look like this one: [img id="2842" width="100%"]
[note]As you can see, the duplicates have been removed.[/note]
[b]TIP:[/b]
If your columns don't match exactly across all queries, you can use a [b]NULL (or any other)[/b] value such as: [code format="sql"]SELECT FirstName, LastName, Company FROM businessContacts
UNION
SELECT FirstName, LastName, [b]NULL [/b]FROM otherContacts;[/code]

quizzes.question: Type in the command to unite the query results without removing the duplicates.
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]UNION ALL[/h1]

[b]UNION ALL[/b] selects all rows from each table and combines them into a single table. 

The following SQL statement uses UNION ALL to select data from the [b]First [/b]and [b]Second [/b]tables: [code format="sql"]SELECT ID, FirstName, LastName, City FROM First
[b]UNION ALL[/b]
SELECT ID, FirstName, LastName, City FROM Second;[/code]
The resulting table: [img id="2843" width="100%"]
[note]As you can see, the result set includes the duplicate rows as well.[/note]
